post_text:
Naugatuck High School artist Melos was busy over the summer creating these stunning pieces.
NHS art teacher Hamandrawatee Pertab had this to say about this work:
"I love the different techniques you combined in the composition. The colors and contrast are also striking. These paintings appear simple yet they carry underlying meanings that are open to the viewer's perception. Great use of Abstraction in regards to lines and color."
.
üé® Want your artwork to be featured on #FineArtFriday? Email your work to laraine.weschler@naugatuck.k12.ct.us or DM us on Facebook or Instagram with your name, grade, and school.
.
#Naugatuck #NaugatuckSchools #StudentArt #StudentArtwork #NaugyArts

post_text:
It is with heavy hearts we mourn the passing of Naugatuck High School social studies teacher Tim Walsh.

Mr. Walsh passed away last night after a long battle with cancer. He began his career as a Social Studies teacher at Naugatuck High School in 1996. Tim was a beloved colleague, teacher, friend, and family member who inspired the best in people.

Below are some pictures from the Closer to Free bike ride and Clash for the Cure basketball tournament benefiting the Smilow Cancer Hospital. ‚ÄúTeam Walsh‚Äù raised tens of thousands of dollars in Tim‚Äôs name. When Tim was well enough after chemotherapy, Tim, in his selfless, strong, and quiet way, participated in the ride himself.

Those of us lucky enough to have known, worked with, or been taught by Tim Walsh are better people for it. Our hearts go out to Tim‚Äôs wife Jill, a teacher at NHS, his two little girls, his sister Deborah Rutigliano, and all that loved him.

shared_text:
Naugatuck Public Schools added 100 new photos ‚Äî in Naugatuck, Connecticut.
September 2 at 5:08 PM ¬∑ Naugatuck, CT ¬∑

Day 1 is in the books! Having our kids back, even with all the safety measures in place, just feels right. Everyone did so good today with wearing their masks and social distancing!
Thank you to our amazing team of administrators, teachers and parents who worked hard all summer long to make this possible, and to our teachers, who have re-learned how to teach in a new world, to our parents, who have been patient and understanding as we navigate these changes together, and to our rock star students, who are going to do awesome things this year!

post_text:
Hello!
We will be holding a Chromebook exchange and pick up on Monday, Aug. 31 from 10 a.m. - 5 p.m. at the NHS auditorium. This event will be for all Kindergarten and 1st-graders. üíª

If you are the parent of a student entering 1st Grade, and you have not yet returned their kindergarten Chromebook, please bring their Chromebook and charger.

If you are the parent of a 1st-grader and you have already exchanged your Chromebook, there is no need to do anything else.

All students entering kindergarten and 1st grade may pick up their new, grade-specific Chromebook Monday.
.
#Naugatuck #NaugatuckSchools #NaugyStrong

üöå The 2020-21 bus routes have been posted on our website https://www.naugatuck.k12.ct.us/apps/pages/transportation.

Please note that bus routes and schedules are subject to change. Due to COVID-19 for parents to please allow a 10-minute window on these times.

Lost items on school buses can be directed to our school bus contractor, STA, at (203) 729-4500.

Any other student transportation issues can be directed to Mary Korowotny, Secretary to the Business Manager, at (203) 720-5265.

post_text:
Just sharing a few ideas you might want to consider to make mask-wearing more comfortable. üò∑ These devices in the first two pictures are called mask brackets and they just sit on your face under the mask to put some separation between your mouth and the mask. They look a bit strange, but supposedly they're quite comfortable and make it easier to breathe and talk. You can find them on Amazon. The second two pictures show how you can sew buttons onto a headband and loop the ear loops around them so they don't rub on your ears.
.
#NaugatuckSchools #NaugyStrong #MaskTips

post_text:
Help us welcome our newest member of the Board of Education, Karen Vassell-Campbell!

Karen was appointed to the Board of Education to fill the remainder of the term for outgoing member Glenn Connan. Her term runs through Oct. 2021.

Karen is a former teacher and now works as a family nurse practitioner. She is committed to helping our district through this pandemic and empowering all enrolled students of Naugatuck School District.

You can read more about her on our website: https://www.naugatuck.k12.ct.us/apps/pages/KarenVassell
.
.
#NaugyBOE #Naugatuck #NaugatuckSchools #BoardofEducation

post_text:
Dear Naugatuck families,
Last year, Connecticut Partnership for Children, Inc. opened two school-based food pantries at Naugatuck High School and Hop Brook Elementary School. This year we have added two additional school-based food pantries at The Naugatuck YMCA and The Early Childhood Center in order to better serve our community.
The Connecticut Partnership for Children, Inc. School-Based Food Pantries are free to access to any family with children in Naugatuck.
Due to Covid-19, we are operating slightly differently than in the past. Order forms will be available weekly, The School-Based Food Pantry Coordinator will fill bags for each family and arrange a time for pick-up.
If you and your family would like to utilize the School-Based Food Pantries, please contact the School-Based Food Pantry Coordinator by texting or emailing ctpfcschoolbasedfoodpantry@gmail.com to discuss which School-Based Food Pantry will best serve you and your family.

Tara Mahoney
School-Based Food Pantry Coordinator
ctpfcschoolbasedfoodpantry@gmail.com

#NaugyStrong #FoodPantry #NaugyFoodPantry @ctpfc

post_text:
Have questions about ParentSquare? (our family communications app) This short video tutorial walks you through everything you need to know!

HERE'S A LITTLE MINI-FAQ:
I can't sign-in: Contact your school secretary to make sure you have the right contact info in our system

I can see one of my kids but not the other: You probably have two accounts because your contact information doesn't match. Contact the school secretary for the child you can't see to make sure they have the right contact info.

How do I sign up? Just go to www.parentsquare.com and enter the cell phone or email address we have on file for you. It will send you a confirmation email or text that you need to click through.

How do I download the app? Search for ParentSquare in Google Play or the Apple App store.

THE FULL FAQ IS ON OUR WEBSITE:
https://www.naugatuck.k12.ct.us/apps/pages/ParentSquareFAQ

‚ùì‚ùì‚ùì If you have any additional questions, drop them in the comments.

post_text:
Students are getting real and planning their futures at Naugatuck High School's Summer Bridge Program for incoming Freshmen. üåâ

We have about 40 students enrolled in the program, which offers students an opportunity to become familiar with the school, connect with other students in teachers, learn skills for succeeding in high school, and earn .5 credits toward graduation. üéì

I asked the students how it felt to be back inside a school building. "Normal," they said.

Thank you, Linda (Bodnar) Pollicita (NHS Class of 2002) for your work as a hospice nurse at VITAS Healthcare. According to Jill McCarthy Bodnar, Linda has had one of the hardest jobs, which is to help people pass away peacefully and without pain. She has assisted many patients who have died of COVID-19. She also would call their families from her cell on FaceTime so they can say their goodbyes.
.

ETA: I'm reading through all your questions and trying to answer as many as I can. I am collecting all your questions to forward to our admin team as well, so if I don't get back to you right away on this feed, rest assured that you are not being ignored. We value all your feedback and questions!

We have released our Return to School plan. Parents & Staff - You should've gotten an email, text or push notification through ParentSquare. If you haven't, please contact your school secretary to update your contact information.

We know you all are feeling anxious about reopening and will have a lot of questions regarding the plan. We are planning virtual forums to answer your questions.

The plan is also on our website at https://www.naugatuck.k12.ct.us/apps/news/article/1262470.

post_text:
Not only did the 2019 Naugatuck Varsity Volleyball Team get it done on the court, Winning the NVL Title, but in the classroom as well! üéìüèêüë®‚Äçüè´
.
They have been awarded The United States Marine Corps (USMC) and the American Volleyball Coaches Association (AVCA) Team Academic Award for the 2019-2020 season!
.
The award, initiated in the 1992-93 academic year, honors volleyball teams that maintain a year-long grade-point average of 3.30 on a 4.0 scale. Our Team Average GPA was an astounding 4.075.
.
We are proud of their efforts on the court, in the classroom and all around! Way to truly represent Naugatuck High School, the community and your families as you are the very definition of a student-athlete and the Vision of the Graduate.
.
More information: https://www.avca.org/awards/avca-team-academic-award.htmlüèêüèê

We are excited for our next school year, with many changes in our administrative team. While many of these faces are familiar to our district, they are new in the roles and schools they will serve. Why wait until the end of summer to get to know each other? I'll be featuring some of our new staff on our social pages in the coming weeks. Help us welcome them in their new roles!

First up, Kristine Murphy-Salvucci would like to introduce herself to our families at Salem Elementary School, where she will serve as principal next year!

post_text:
The Naugatuck Board of Education is currently seeking interested candidates to fill a vacancy on its Board. The Board will be accepting letters of interest and resumes from interested candidates through Friday, July 31, 2020. Applicants must be 18 years of age or older and a registered voter with a political party affiliation in the Borough of Naugatuck. The candidate selected will complete the current term of the vacancy, which ends November 2021 and may also seek re-election during the November 2021 municipal elections.
.
For consideration, please send a letter of interest and resume to Janice Myers, Board Secretary via email at janice.myers@naugatuck.k12.ct.us or via mail to 497 Rubber Avenue, Naugatuck, CT 06770.
.
We'd like to thank outgoing Board of Education member Glenn Connan for his service to the board and our students.

post_text:
When Katie Singley's students describe her, several themes emerge. Ms. Singley makes learning fun, shares laughter with her students, and keeps them engaged and thinking deeply about relevent topics. She makes them feel comfortable making mistakes and helps them work through their problems.

It's no wonder she was chosen as our 2019-20 Teacher of the Year! We're proud to have Ms. Singley teaching in our district. Her love her students and Naugatuck shines through in the work she does.

Congratulations Katie!

post_text:
Update: The state is experiencing problems with the downloads that districts sent to them for the distribution of the P-EBT cards which has caused cards to be mailed to incorrect addresses.

Unfortunately, there is nothing any of us in the district can do to help.

If your P-EBT card was sent to the wrong address, call 1-855-626-6632 and follow the prompts. Explain to the person that answers the phone that the card went to the incorrect address, give them the correct address, and request that the "information be sent to the SNAP TEAM to review."
That is the only way to get a new card issued.
shared_text:

Update: The state is experiencing problems with the downloads that districts sent to them for the distribution of the P-EBT cards which has caused cards to be mailed to incorrect addresses.

Unfortunately, there is nothing any of us in the district can do to help.

If your P-EBT card was sent to the wrong address, call 1-855-626-6632 and follow the prompts. Explain to the person that answers the phone that the card went to the incorrect address, give them the correct address, and request that the "information be sent to the SNAP TEAM to review."
That is the only way to get a new card issued.

PORTAL.CT.GOV
Food Assistance - SNAP

She wrote,
"Thank you all so much for everything you do for me and making School and Learning fun for me. I appreciate you all so much and can't wait to get back to School. I'll never take School for granted again. I miss you all and I hope you like the video. I had a lot of fun making it. Thank You!!!!!!!!!!"

UPDATE: Spaces are filling up quickly! Don't miss out on this amazing opportunity. We only have 4 spots left in the 10-12 time slot. 20 spots are open for the 8-10am time slot. Call Deb Bradley at 203-720-5400 or email johnna.hunt@naugatuck.k12.ct.us to enroll your child.

To our rising 9th-grade class: Get a jump start on your high school career! üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è
Enroll in Naugatuck High School's Summer Bridge Program! üåû

This program offers incoming freshmen an opportunity to:
üéì Become familiar with our school
üéì Connect with other students and teachers
üéì Learn valuable skills to succeed in high school
üéì All while earning .5 credits toward graduation!

üóì Aug. 3 - Aug. 21
In-person classes at NHS Monday-Thursday.
Online class on Fridays.

Two sessions:
8 a.m. - 10 a.m.
10 a.m. to 12 p.m.

To enroll or get more information, call Deb Bradley at 203-720-5400 or email johnna.hunt@naugatuck.k12.ct.us.

Space is limited. Enrollment is on a first-come, first-served basis.
Enrollment closes July 24.

post_text:
To our incoming 10th, 11th, and 12th-graders:

In-person pre-season conditioning for fall sport returning athletes grades 10,11,12 will begin on Wednesday, July 8, 2020. In order to participate, you must sign-up online.

Due to COVID-19 regulations, student-athletes will be placed into training cohorts, if you do not register via the link you will not be able to participate.

Once registered, your coach will email you specifics such as training times and dates, check-in time, training location, cohort assignment, and COVID-19 regulations that need to be followed for each training session.

https://naugatuckschools.formstack.com/forms/summer2020conditioning

post_text:
We'd like to wish Nancy Sasso Janis the best in her retirement! She is retiring after working with 37 classes of first grade and kindergarten students, 32 of them in Naugatuck. üëèüëèüëè

‚ÄúThank you to the wonderful parents that I have met throughout the years. Thank you to the dedicated teachers and staff members who supported me right up to my final day in the classroom. Thank you to my fellow Naugatuck Teachers League representatives for their unwavering service. Most importantly, thank you to all of the hundreds of students that it has been my pleasure to teach; I am so very proud of you all. Special congratulations to the class of 2020...how I missed watching you walk across the stage to receive your diploma. Please know that your first-grade teacher is proud of you.‚Äù
.
NPS Retirees: If you haven't yet sent me a photo and sentence or two you'd like to share so we can celebrate you, please do send it to laraine.weschler@naugatuck.k12.ct.us
.
#NaugyStrong #NaugyGoesTheDistance #Naugatuck #NaugatuckSchools

post_text:
Yesterday, we bid a virtual good-bye to our guiding light of the last 6 years, Superintendent Sharon Locke.

Ms. Locke has championed each and every student during her time at Naugatuck Public Schools. Her impact on our schools has been profound and will be long-lasting. A passionate, tenacious leader and a logical problem-solver, Sharon has challenged our staff while pushing us to be better. We look forward to continuing her work under the leadership of Chris Montini.

We wish her well in the next stage of her career!
text:

A passionate, tenacious leader and a logical problem-solver, Sharon has challenged our staff while pushing us to be better. We look forward to continuing her work under the leadership of Chris Montini.

We wish her well in the next stage of her career!

post_text:
Wishing Coach Sollazzo the best in his retirement! üèà

"After three great years as Head Football coach of the greyhounds, with much thought, I have decided to retire. This has been one of the most difficult decisions of my life. I have been fortunate to have had the opportunity to work with many great players, parents, and coaches. To my co-workers and families of my players all have worked so hard to make Naugtauck a tremendous community.

Saying goodbye to my returning players is the hardest part of all this, though I know they will move on and accomplish great things. I will miss the daily contact during the season with some of the finest student athletes and just great individuals here at Naugatuck."

- David Sollazzo
text:
Wishing Coach Sollazzo the best in his retirement! üèà

"After three great years as Head Football coach of the greyhounds, with much thought, I have decided to retire. This has been one of the most difficult decisions of my life. I have been fortunate to have had the opportunity to work with many great players, parents, and coaches. To my co-workers and families of my players all have worked so hard to make Naugtauck a tremendous community.

Saying goodbye to my returning players is the hardest part of all this, though I know they will move on and accomplish great things. I will miss the daily contact during the season with some of the finest student athletes and just great individuals here at Naugatuck."

- David Sollazzo

post_text:
Have you ever wondered where your food comes from? ü•íü•¨ü•ïüçÖ

Join Miss Claire from the Naugatuck Farm to School team as she tours Sunset Farm, right here in Naugatuck! Farmer Kaitlyn Kimball gave us a behind-the-scenes look at what they're growing this season and how they care for the plants and animals.

If your student has questions about something mentioned in the video, comment below for an answer from someone on the Naugy Farm to School team!

After watching the video, be sure to check out Sunset Farm for some locally grown organic produce and other items this Summer!

#naugygrows #foodcorpsct #Naugatuck #NaugatuckSchools

Talking about race can be hard. We've compiled some resources for teachers and families to learn more about systemic racism, how to talk about race, and learning more about equity. These resources have been recommended by our NPS faculty and other educational and equity experts.

https://sites.google.com/naugatuck.k12.ct.us/npsproflearning/racial-equity
shared_text:
SITES.GOOGLE.COM
NPS - Racial Equity
text:
Talking about race can be hard. We've compiled some resources for teachers and families to learn more about systemic racism, how to talk about race, and learning more about equity. These resources have been recommended by our NPS faculty and other educational and equity experts.

https://sites.google.com/naugatuck.k12.ct.us/npsproflearning/racial-equity

SITES.GOOGLE.COM
NPS - Racial Equity

post_text:
Kudos to Naugatuck High School student Alyssa Bowes for creating this awesome animation!

I don't know if any of you all have tried making an animation before, but I have, and I can tell you first-hand that it is hard work! Great job Alyssa, and graphics teacher John Forish!

post_text:
During our virtual ceremony, we missed announcing Masin Warner's name and displaying his slide. üéì

To try to make up for it, we're giving Masin some well-deserved recognition on all of our social media outlets today. üë®‚Äçüéì

Masin, please know how proud all of us at NHS are of all of your accomplishments! ü•≥üëè

Masin's slide will be included in a final version of the virtual graduation ceremony, which will be shared through Google Drive for anyone who wants to download it in the next few weeks.

post_text: While Juneteenth was the official end of slavery, it has not been the end of racism in our country. We celebrate the ending of a most terrible American institution, and we continue to fight for racial equity in our communities, schools, and nation.
text: While Juneteenth was the official end of slavery, it has not been the end of racism in our country. We celebrate the ending of a most terrible American institution, and we continue to fight for racial equity in our communities, schools, and nation.

post_text:
Congratulations to our new Coordinator of the Early Childhood Center at Central Avenue, Meagan Rolla!

She will be replacing Kristine Murphy-Salvucci, who is moving on to become the principal of Salem Elementary School as of July 1, 2020.

Meagan has been working as our lead counselor where she has helped roll out the RULER social-emotional learning program to all our schools.
@ruler_approach

Please help us welcome her in her new role!

post_text:
A beautiful performance by our City Hill Middle School 8th Grade band!

On the last day of school that we were together, our CHMS Band teacher Kathy Dravis recorded this 8th-grade band rehearsal and put together a virtual concert, two months before the real concert was supposed to happen.

We hope you can enjoy it now!

Do you have a musical recording you'd like to share? Email laraine.weschler@naugatuck.k12.ct.us to be included in a future #TunefulTuesday.

post_text:
Our summer meal program begins June 15! üçïüçé
.
Free meals for children under 18 will be available from 11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. each weekday at nine locations; Naugatuck High School, Lantern Park, the Early Childhood Center at Central Avenue, Andrew Avenue Elementary, Maple Hill Elementary, Hop Brook Elementary, City Hill Middle School, Western Elmentary School and Salem Elementary School.
.
We will not be serving meals Friday, June 12, so make sure to pick up two meals on Thursday!
.
#NaugyGoesTheDistance #summermealsprogram #Naugatuck #NaugatuckSchools #SchoolLunch

post_text:
Teachers across our district are getting a final chance to wave goodbye to their students this week as they come to pick up their belongings and free Scholastic book packs for every PK-8 child thanks to the State Department of
Education and a generous donation from the Nooyi Family! üëãüìö

It's a bitter-sweet end to a historic year for our schools. We hope that everyone enjoys their final week of virtual learning! Make sure to thank your teachers for all the work they've put in to making the best experience possible for our students as they changed their entire way of teaching to adapt to these times. üë©‚Äçüè´

üíö = low energy, high pleasantness (grateful, secure, at ease, chill, relieved, humble, etc.)

post_text:
We're excited to welcome three new principals to our schools for the 2020-21 school year! üëèü§©üëè

üë©‚Äçüè´ Current Salem Elementary School Principal Tiffany Deitelbaum will move over to Cross Street Intermediate School, replacing Melissa Cooney, who is moving up to serve as our assistant superintendent.

üë©‚Äçüè´ Current Early Childhood Center Coordinator Kristine Murphy-Salvucci will become the new principal for Salem Elementary School

üë©‚Äçüè´ And Giovanna Testani, an assistant principal at an elementary school in Bridgeport, will serve as the new principal of Hillside Intermediate School, replacing Johnna Hunt, who is moving up as Assistant Principal of Naugatuck High School.

Please help us welcome these talented women to their new roles!

post_text:
Congratulations to Naugatuck High School Senior Alysha Cacace, who was recently recognized by the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education with a student leadership award. üëèüëèüëè

Students are nominated to receive this award by their school principal. Students nominated should exhibit the following leadership skills:

üèÖWillingness to take on challenges
üèÖCapability to make difficult decisions
üèÖConcern for others
üèÖAbility to work with others
üèÖWillingness to commit to a project
üèÖDiplomacy
üèÖAbility to understand issues clearly
üèÖAbility to honor a commitment
.
#NaugyGoesTheDistance #StudentLeader #studentleadership #Naugatuck #NaugatuckSchools

Please pick up your meals for Monday on Friday, May 22. üçï

The daily menu has been updated for the rest of the academic year and is on our website at http://bit.ly/NaugyMenu. üçé

Children do not need to be present in order to collect the meals. üçïü•™üçé

The 11 school meal sites will be open each weekday from 11 am - 1 pm through June 11.

We will be closed June 12th but passing out 2 meals on Thursday, June 11th.

Summer meals will start on Monday, June 15th. Summer meals will be served for only 1 hour, 11:30 a.m. -12:30 p.m. at the following sites: Andrew Ave School, Western School, Salem School, Hop Brook School, Maple Hill School, City Hill Middle School, Naugatuck High School and Lantern Park. We will not be serving summer meals at Cross School or Southwood Apartments.

#NaugyGoesTheDistance

Monday #MoodMeter check-in.

Let's see how many feelings words we can think of! Can you name an emotion no one else will think of?

How are you feeling today?
Comment with a heart: ‚ù§Ô∏èüíõüíöüíô
‚ù§Ô∏è = high energy, low pleasantness (angry, peeved, uneasy, worried, nervous, frightened, restless, etc.)
üíõ = high energy, high pleasantness (cheerful, inspired, lively, proud, optimistic, upbeat, etc.)
üíö = low energy, high pleasantness (grateful, secure, at ease, chill, relieved, humble, etc.)
üíô = low energy, low pleasantness (bored, lonely, tired, drained, disappointed, etc.)

#NaugyGoesTheDistance #Naugatuck #NaugatuckSchools #MoodMeter The RULER Approach

post_text:
"My two favorite teachers/faculty members are Miss Maza and Mrs. Cammarata. They have both been incredible mentors to me, and brought out my potential each day. They have taught me so many life lessons, given me advice when I needed it, and inspired me to be the best version of myself. I could not have done everything I did in high school without them.

I will miss being involved the most. I was in many clubs and organizations and spent my free time trying to benefit Naugy in any way that I could. I loved being connected to staff and faculty, along with many students. Naugatuck gave me many opportunities and pathways to be involved and still have fun while doing it, which is something I will greatly miss." - Alysha, Naugatuck High School Class of 2020

Seniors - Fill out the Google Form at bit.ly/NHSSeniorSpotlight2020 to be included in the Senior Spotlights.

The University of Alabama

post_text:
üíªThe number #1 we're getting with Chromebooks is that they will not turn on. Before contacting your teacher for a replacement, please try the following steps:

üîå Is the charger‚Äôs power cord damaged in some way, i.e. broken or exposed wires, broken plug end, or a broken charger connection on the device? Do not use it if damaged in any way and request a replacement.

üîå If there are no broken wires or plugs, plug the Chromebook into the charger and the charger into the wall outlet, wait for 5 to 10 minutes, then open the cover to see if it will start now. Press and hold the power button if necessary to attempt to start the device.

üîå If you have a Lenovo 100e or 300e Chromebook and it still doesn‚Äôt turn on, try to plug the AC adapter into the USB Type C charging port on the other side of the Chromebook. There are two of these ports on the Chromebook that can be used for charging.

‚ùì Having a different issue with your Chromebook? Visit our troubleshooting page at: https://www.naugatuck.k12.ct.us/apps/pages/
chromebooktroubleshooting

üîå If there are no broken wires or plugs, plug the Chromebook into the charger and the charger into the wall outlet, wait for 5 to 10 minutes, then open the cover to see if it will start now. Press and hold the power button if necessary to attempt to start the device.

üîå If you have a Lenovo 100e or 300e Chromebook and it still doesn‚Äôt turn on, try to plug the AC adapter into the USB Type C charging port on the other side of the Chromebook. There are two of these ports on the Chromebook that can be used for charging.

Naugatuck High School
May 13 at 5:09 PM ¬∑

Each year with the support of Ion Bank, Naugatuck High School recognizes the sophomores, juniors, and seniors that rank in the top 5% of their class. This event was started by former Director of Counseling Richard Robinson and has become a favorite of many staff and students.

Seniors select an NPS staff member to speak on their behalf, new members to the top 5% are presented with a jacket, varsity letter, and lamp of knowledge pin and sustaining members receive a chevron bar to add to their letter each year they remain in the top 5%.

This year, since we cannot celebrate our students' achievements in person, we've created a video honoring the top of our class.

Please congratulate the following students on their achievement.

post_text:
Right now, if we were still in our buildings, we would be at the height of the spring concert season. Just because we can't perform together doesn't mean we can't still appreciate the amazing talent of our students. üé∂

Starting today, I will be posting performances by our amazing student musicians every Tuesday with the hashtag #TunefulTuesday. üéº

What better way to start off, than with our amazing Naugatuck High School jazz band?! With a special guest performance by Principal John Harris!

post_text:
Message from Superintendent Locke: Distance Learning, end-of-year plans, book packs, and P-EBT cards:
https://www.naugatuck.k12.ct.us/apps/news/article/1225181

Questions and Answers about the P-EBT cards for Naugatuck K-12 students: https://www.naugatuck.k12.ct.us/apps/pages/p-ebt

The Pandemic Debit Card (P-EBT) is a program by the CT Department of Social Services, not the town or the school system. They tell us that if students do not attend our schools but receive SNAP, participate in HUSKY A, or are eligible for free lunch in another school, they will also receive the P-EBT benefit. The program is designed to help address food insecurity issues during the current COVID crisis.

Questions should be directed to EBT Customer Service
1-888-328-2666
Available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week

EBT customer service website:
www.ct.gov/dss/ebt

NAUGATUCK.K12.CT.US
Naugatuck School District

post_text: Gov. Lamont just announced that in-person classes will be canceled for the rest of the academic year. We will be continuing distance learning and school meals at our 11 pick-up locations. Superintendent Locke will be sending out a message to our families with more information about our plans going forward this weekend.
shared_text:
Office of Governor Ned Lamont
May 5 at 9:45 AM ¬∑

BREAKING: Due to the ongoing pandemic, in-person classes at K-12 schools in Connecticut will remain canceled for the rest of the academic year. Given the circumstances, this is the best course of action for the safety of students, educators, and staff.

DETAILS: https://bit.ly/2WoBw6Q
text:

Seniors - Fill out the Google Form at bit.ly/NHSSeniorSpotlight2020 to be included in the Senior Spotlights.

Even though we won't be in school, the counseling department still plans to host a virtual Decision Day, so make sure you post pictures with your college, military or career gear to Instagram, Twitter or Facebook on May 1 with the hashtags #NationalDecisionDay, #ClassOf2020, and #Naugy2020! Tag Naugatuck Public Schools and we'll share your good news!

post_text:
"One thing I‚Äôll miss about Naugy High is the new friendship I have made at the beginning of the school year, and the JROTC class also the ESL class. Those two classes have been a really big part of my life, it was the greatest years with those two classes because they have helped me on always trying my best when I didn't have my English on the best levels. They have helped me build it up until I get to my best and I am really grateful for them, and I really could not ask for more than what they have done for me!" - Moises, Naugatuck High School Class of 2020

post_text:
Our teachers have had to adapt their entire way of teaching in a matter of days, learn new technology, and find ways to connect with their students virtually. We know they always go above-and-beyond for our students, but this year, I think they deserve an extra round of applause.

Help us celebrate Teacher Appreciation Week (May 4-8) with a special tribute.

Send us a short video clip or piece of artwork explaining how a teacher impacted your life so we can put together a special thank-you. We'd especially like to hear about how they've helped you through this unprecedented pandemic.

Please email laraine.weschler@naugatuck.k12.ct.us or DM us on Facebook or Instagram with your submissions!

post_text:
The Early Childhood Center at Central Avenue is excited to announce that we will now be accepting preschool enrollment for the children of all Naugatuck residents. üëßüë¶

This NAEYC accredited program has 10-month or 12-month options.
The cost is $250 per week, which includes meals and snacks.

Interested families can reach out to our parent advocates:
barbara.fecteau@naugatuck.k12.ct.us
crystal.gordon@naugatuck.k12.ct.us

Children must turn 3 by Dec. 31, 2020 to participate in the program.

See our Frequently Asked Questions page to learn more about our program!
https://ecc.naugatuck.k12.ct.us/apps/pages/index.jsp?uREC_ID=957627&type=d&pREC_ID=1923377

We were deeply saddened to hear about the death of Naugatuck Education Foundation Chairman Fred Scheithe yesterday after his long battle with cancer. A former teacher, basketball coach, and all-around advocate for Naugatuck's children, Fred will be greatly missed.

Some of his students and fans got a chance to say goodbye to him Friday, from a distance.

Monday #MoodMeter check-in. Hope everyone is enjoying their April vacation!

Who is someone who makes you feel in the green or yellow (happy, excited) on the mood meter? Tag them!

How are you feeling?
Comment with a heart: ‚ù§Ô∏èüíõüíöüíô
‚ù§Ô∏è = high energy, low pleasantness (angry, peeved, uneasy, worried, nervous, frightened, restless, etc.)
üíõ = high energy, high pleasantness (cheerful, inspired, lively, proud, optimistic, upbeat, etc.)
üíö = low energy, high pleasantness (grateful, secure, at ease, chill, relieved, humble, etc.)
üíô = low energy, low pleasantness (bored, lonely, tired, drained, disappointed, etc.)
.
.
.

"The thing I will miss the most about Naugy is the marching band. I was part of the band for 5 years and I made a lot of my friends in the program. It was the best experience of my life and it taught me so much. My favorite teacher is definitely Mr. Hughes. He helped me grow into a great musician and person and I will be forever grateful for that." - Lindsey Schulte, NHS Class of 2020

post_text:
State press release announced April 9:

Governor Lamont and Education Commissioner Cardona announce plans to extend the cancellation of classes at schools until at least May 20.

Governor Lamont, in consultation with State Education Commissioner Miguel Cardona, today announced that he soon plans to sign an executive order extending the date for which classes at all public schools statewide remain canceled until at least May 20.

‚ÄúOut of the best interests of the health and safety of students, teachers, and staff, we feel this is the best approach at this time,‚Äù Governor Lamont said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll continue consulting with our public health experts and education officials in the coming weeks as the situation continues to change. I want everyone to know that this is done out of an abundance of caution, and our education officials will continue to speak with school districts to help amplify their learn-from-home initiatives during this difficult time.‚Äù

The governor plans to sign the order in the coming days.

Naugatuck Public Schools will continue updating you as plans evolve.

‚ÄúOut of the best interests of the health and safety of students, teachers, and staff, we feel this is the best approach at this time,‚Äù Governor Lamont said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll continue consulting with our public health experts and education officials in the coming weeks as the situation continues to change. I want everyone to know that this is done out of an abundance of caution, and our education officials will continue to speak with school districts to help amplify their learn-from-home initiatives during this difficult time.‚Äù

The governor plans to sign the order in the coming days.

Naugatuck Public Schools will continue updating you as plans evolve.

post_text:
We are going on a Bear Hunt April 8-17! üêª

Our Early Childhood Center at Central Ave School program would like to ask each family to put a stuffed animal or drawing/picture of a bear in their window or door so when families go for a walk the kids can go on a ‚ÄúBear Hunt.‚Äù

This idea is based on the beloved children‚Äôs book "We are going on a Bear Hunt" by Michael Rosen and Helen Oxenbury. It‚Äôs also a song we love to sing with our students at school. Share the idea with others so they can start this in their neighborhood too!!

If you are participating, please post a photo of your bear in the comments, or your street address, if you're comfortable with that so the kids know where to look!
.
.
#NaugyGoesTheDistance #NaugyStrong #NaugatuckSchools #Naugatuck #goingonabearhunt

post_text:
Hi Folks!

We will be serving free breakfast and lunch for children under 18 during Spring Break on Monday and Wednesday only, according to the following schedule:

üçè We are closed on Friday, April 10 but we will be passing out the meal on Thursday, April 9. You will get 2 meal bags per child on Thursday.

üçê Monday, April 13: You will get meal bags for both Monday and Tuesday

üçë Wednesday April 15: You will get 3 meal bags per child. (1 for Wednesday, 1 for Thursday and 1 for Friday)

All 11 sites will be open from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. on those days.

We will be back to the 5 days a week starting on April 20th.

The menu has not yet been finalized and is subject to change.

Pick-up sites are located at:
Naugatuck High School
Southwood Garden
Lantern Park
Central Ave.
Andrew Ave.
Maple Hill
Hop Brook
City Hill
Cross St.
Western
Salem

post_text:
Monday #MoodMeter check-in. Embarking on our 3rd week of distance learning.

If you have felt like you've been in the blue or red quadrant this week, (overwhelmed or lonely, anyone?), tell us about one strategy you use to shift your mood to the blue or yellow?

How are you feeling?
Comment with a heart: ‚ù§Ô∏èüíõüíöüíô
‚ù§Ô∏è = high energy, low pleasantness (angry, peeved, uneasy, worried, nervous, frightened, restless, etc.)
üíõ = high energy, high pleasantness (cheerful, inspired, lively, proud, optimistic, upbeat, etc.)
üíö = low energy, high pleasantness (grateful, secure, at ease, chill, relieved, humble, etc.)
üíô = low energy, low pleasantness (bored, lonely, tired, drained, disappointed, etc.)
.
.
.
#NaugyGoesTheDistance

post_text:
"I'm going to miss my teachers and all the friends I've made at NHS." - Alivia

Naugatuck High School Senior Alivia will be attending Southern Connecticut State University in the fall and majoring in nursing!

Seniors - Send your photo with your name, post-high school destination, intended major and/or career, favorite teacher, and what you'll miss about NHS to laraine.weschler@naugatuck.k12.ct.us or DM us on Facebook or Instagram.

Even though we won't be in school, the counseling department still plans to host a virtual Decision Day, so make sure you post pictures with your college, military or career gear to Instagram, Twitter or Facebook on May 1 with the hashtags #NationalDecisionDay, #ClassOf2020, and #Naugy2020! Tag Naugatuck Public Schools and we'll share your good news!

#NaugySeniors @naugatuck2020 #Naugy2020 #classof2020 #NaugyGoesTheDistance #NaugatuckCT #NaugatuckSchools #Naugatuck #NaugyStrong #SeniorSpotlight

post_text:
On Wednesday, our IT Department, with help from security, exchanged about 30 broken Chromebooks, while our food services staff gave out 150 meals at Naugatuck High School.

Thank you to both departments for your efforts to keep our kids fed and ready to learn!

From now on, if your Chromebook is broken, please contact your teacher. We do not have another Chromebook exchange planned at the high school at this time.

post_text:
Our friends at the Naugatuck Police Department want our K-12 students to help them design PSA Posters on how to be safe during COVID-19 or First Responders in Our Community!

Guidelines for Submitting work:
Work can be done digitally or drawn on paper.
Work should be appropriate and convey a positive message.
The work should reflect one of the two choices above.
Students and parents, submission of the project is consent to post. Please
email your art teacher with a photo of your work, your first and last name, grade level and school.

Target deadline: April 8

Selected artwork will be featured on the NPD Facebook page

If your Chromebook is physically broken, please bring it to Naugatuck High School on Wednesday, April 1, from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. to be repaired and pick up a replacement. Please also bring your charger. üíª

If you or a family member are ill, do not come! Email your teacher or school principal and we will make other arrangements for you. Thank you for helping keep everyone safe.

If you are having a technical problem using your Chromebook, please email your teacher for help.

post_text:
Congratulations to NHS senior John Mezzo, who will be attending and continuing to play football at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, in Worcester, MA next year! üèà

Jay is a three-sport senior athlete at Naugatuck High School. He has been playing football for 8 years and has had the honor of serving as a captain of Naugatuck High School's Football team for the past two years. He was named to the All-Iron Division team this past season.

"After a long recruiting process, I have decided that WPI is the best school for me, athletically and academically and I look forward to what the future holds," Jay said.

Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI) WPI Athletics

post_text:
#NaugyGoesTheDistance won the overwhelming majority of votes in our distance learning hashtag contest! üíª

I will be using this hashtag for all our distance learning posts going forward to make it easy for you to follow along!

I invite you to do the same! I'll be posting occasional prompts and share some of your responses when you use the hashtag if your account is public. Let's stay connected, Naugatuck! We're in this together! ‚ù§Ô∏è

Also, thank-you Kelly Tremlett for submitting this hashtag!

post_text:
Hopefully, by now, you've heard of The RULER Approach, our district-wide social-emotional learning program. üíôüíöüíõ‚ù§Ô∏è

In this time of uncertainty, learning to understand and regulate our emotions is more important than ever.

I'd like to invite parents to tune in to this free webinar offered by the Yale Center For Emotional Intelligence at 3 p.m. this afternoon. You can register at the link below.

Today's topic is: Ideas for Practice and Play with Emotional Intelligence.
Wednesday, March 25, 3 p.m. ET.
In this webinar, Robin Stern, associate director, Jessica Hoffmann, director of high school initiatives, and Kathryn Lee, director of RULER for Families ‚Äî all of the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence ‚Äî will explore ways we can develop our emotional skills together using the Mood Meter, RULER games, and prompts to get everyone talking about their emotions.
shared_text:
NEWS.YALE.EDU
Yale webinars: Using emotional intelligence to combat COVID-19 anxiety

post_text:
Congratulations to our culinary students who took home medals in the Family Community Career Leaders of America culinary competition at Naugatuck Valley Community College March 6! üë©‚Äçüç≥üë®‚Äçüç≥

ü•áMadison McEachern, Tyvias Dippelhofer, and Brielle Behuniak won gold in the baking and pastry competition, with their patte au choux, shortbread cookies, and cheddar biscuits. They each won a $1,000 scholarship to Johnson & Wales University. üç™

ü•áRebecca Carney won gold for cake decorating with her design which included a rose with a leaf, vine, numbers, a shell border and had "Best Wishes" written on it. Rebecca won a $1,000 scholarship to The Culinary Institute of America. Madison Nunes and Logan Schultz also competed in cake decorating. üéÇ

Although they didn't come home with a medal, Devin Giove, John Hall, and Alexus Ferrari did an amazing job in the Food Service Event, creating dishes including chicken breast with mushroom sauce, braised zucchini, mashed potatoes, rice and red pepper pilaf, and sauteed cabbage. ü•íü•¨ü•î

Fourth-grade students from each of our elementary schools competed to create and cook a recipe reimagining their favorite school lunch meal. The students had an hour and a half to cook their recipe for a panel of judges with assistance from Sodexo USA cooks and our FoodCorps Connecticut volunteer.

Congratulations to our runners-up - Rudy Bush from Hop Brook Elementary School, Austin Durkin from Andrew Avenue Elementary, Abby Hawks from Western, and Chloe Whipple from Salem Elementary School!

You can find all their delicious recipes at http://bit.ly/FutureChefsNaugy2020

post_text:
Congratulations to Melissa Cooney, who has been appointed our new Assistant Superintendent of Schools beginning July 1!

Melissa has been the principal of Cross Street Intermediate School since July 2013 and prior to that she served from July 2008 to June 2013 as the principal of Western Elementary School. Melissa has a vested interest in our public schools as an administrator, community member and most importantly a parent. She will bring her wealth of knowledge and experience to this critical position.

We know that Melissa will be a dedicated and trusted partner to incoming Superintendent Chris Montini and together they will lead our district to new levels and continue to make positive improvements.

We are all excited for our incoming administration and the impact they will have on our students and district. Please join me in congratulating Melissa and wishing her all the best on her appointment as Assistant Superintendent of the Naugatuck Public Schools.

Sincerely,

Jeffrey Litke
Chair, Naugatuck Board of Education

post_text:
The Naugatuck Parent School Council is Accepting Nominations for Raymond K. Foley Award. üèÜ

Named in honor of Raymond K. Foley, an example of what dedication and service to children represent. This award, presented by the Naugatuck Parent School Council (PSC), honors an individual or group who has demonstrated outstanding service and unselfish dedication contributing to the betterment of Naugatuck children.

The nominee must have demonstrated outstanding service, on a volunteer basis, for at least 5 years. Nominations can be made online at https://forms.gle/9jRKtayJSiNugEb27. For more information, please feel free to contact Melissa Teator by email at mateator@gmail.com. Nominees will be invited to complete a detailed application. Nominations must be received by March 16, 2020.

post_text:
We are excited to announce on behalf of our CHMS Energy Drink Group that HB 5141 An Act To Prohibit The Sale Of Energy Drinks To Persons Under the Age of 16 has passed out of committee!

It was voted out of committee and will now go to the House. Connecticut is now the first state in the country to successfully get an energy drink bill out of committee!

And even better (unexpected news) is that committee members felt with the information presented that 16 was too young - the bill is moving forward for persons under the age of 18!

These kids have worked so hard and accomplished something so incredibly special - even with the American Beverage Association, Red Bull, and several other consumer agencies lobbying against them. We thank you all for your continued support!

Our students are becoming responsible citizens and learning that they can affect change.

post_text:
We couldn't be more proud of our City Hill Middle School science students for their testimony this week on a state bill that would ban the sale of energy drinks to children under 16.

Last year, 7th-grade science students studied the effects of energy drinks on adolescents, then presented their findings to State Rep. Liz Linehan. She was so impressed with their work that she drafted a bill with students' input. The students testified on behalf of their bill and lobbied legislators, but it got stuck in committee last year. This year, the bill was brought back up and a new crop of 7th graders had the chance to testify on their research before the state Committee on Children this week.

We have high hopes that will move out of committee and go to a vote in the legislature this session!

Students also met with parents whose children died from complications related to energy drink consumption.

Energy Drink Awareness Liz Linehan

üíñPlease call your child's school to set up an appointment time.

Is your child eating breakfast? ü•Øüçéüçäüçåü•Ø

Our nurses are reporting students coming to them mid-morning with tummy aches because they didn't eat breakfast.

Breakfast at all Naugatuck schools is free and nutritious!

Encourage your kids to take a school breakfast each day. Even if they don't want it right away, they can always save it to have as a snack later.

Students learn better on a full belly!

post_text:
Congratulations to Johnna Hunt for being appointed as the associate principal of Naugatuck High School, effective July 1!

For the past ten years, Johnna has led Hillside Intermediate School - Naugatuck as it's principal. In 2014, she was named the CT State Principal of the Year, and during the 2014-2015 school year, she served as Principal Leader In-Residence at the CT State Dept. of Education's Talent Office.

Johnna was also an adjunct professor at the University of Cincinnati's Educational Leadership program. Prior to her role as principal, Johnna taught social studies and math at Hillside Middle School from 2000-2009.

Johnna is a lifelong resident of Naugatuck, a graduate of NHS, and bleeds garnet and grey. üêæ

post_text:
Have you always been curious about where you came from? üå≥

This workshop is designed for those just beginning to trace their family tree. You will be provided with a slide show presentation that features many resources researchers can use to begin their search into their ancestors with a focus on American records. There will be a guided work session, during which students begin their research and have access to some of the instructors paid genealogical subscriptions. The second night of class will be digging deeper into your family tree and breakthrough some roadblocks. You will learn to solve challenging ancestral mysteries and also be introduced to international research. In both sessions, there will be time spent on research.

Class begins March 3.
shared_text:
NAUGATUCKADULTED.COURSESTORM.COM
Research Your Roots | Naugatuck Adult and Continuing Education

post_text:
Happy 100th Day of School! üíØ

Today was also the 1,000th day of school since Kindergarten for our 5th graders! Hillside Intermediate School - Naugatuck teachers surprised their students with a fun day of math and literacy centers related to the number 1,000. Students were then asked to reflect on what lies ahead for day 2,000 (the start of their junior year).

This was particularly exciting because the 5th-grade math curriculum is based around the powers of 10 and the relationship between 10, 100 and 1,000 (and decimals). The staff also created a great kick-off video and wore matching t-shirts. Check out Hillside's Facebook page for the video.

Our elementary schools celebrated their 100th Day in School this year by dressing up as 100-year-olds, bringing collections of 100 things and participating in fun academic activities based around the number 100. Stay tuned for photos of the most adorable senior citizens ever! üëµüë¥

post_text:
Congratulations to Jaida Taveras, winner of the American Legion Post 17 oratorical contest! üá∫üá∏ Jaida is on fire lately! üî• She just came in 3rd place in Naugatuck High School's Poetry Out Loud: National Recitation Contest. üéô

The Legion said that contestants Mikayla Williams and Spencer Maher were also remarkably well prepared! Each contestant delivered an 8-10 minute oration on a constitutional topic of their choosing, and then a 3-5 minute oration on one of four randomly drawn constitution topics.

Jaida will now represent our Post and town in the District contest at 9 a.m. Saturday at Post 17, 21 Cedar St., Naugatuck. She will be competing against contestants from Cheshire, Guilford, and Milford.

Please join us in supporting Jaida as she competes! üëè
